articles.title: The Bright Side: UNESCO designates 26 new biosphere reserves including France's Lake Bourget
articles.summary: United Nations cultural agency UNESCO has designated 26 new biosphere reserves across 21 countries to tackle biodiversity challenges and worsening climate change. Lake Bourget in the French Alps was among those listed along with the marshes and tides between France's Loire and Vilaine rivers.
articles.content:
A woman protects herself from the sun along Lake Bourget, in Le Bourget-du-Lac, in the French Alps, on August 8, 2025.

An Indonesian archipelago that's home to three-fourths of Earth's coral species, a stretch of Icelandic coast with 70 percent of the country's plant life and an area along Angola's Atlantic coast featuring savannahs, forests and estuaries are among 26 new UNESCO-designated biosphere reserves.

Lake Bourget in the French Alps was among the areas designated a biosphere reserve – with the UN citing its more than 6,100 listed animal and plant species – along with the marshes and tides between the Loire and the Vilaine rivers.

The United Nations cultural agency says the reserves – 785 sites in 142 countries, designated since 1971 – are home to some of the planet’s richest and most fragile ecosystems. But biosphere reserves encompass more than strictly protected nature reserves; they're expanded to include areas where people live and work, and the designation requires that scientists, residents and government officials work together to balance conservation and research with local economic and cultural needs.

Read moreThe Bright Side: Malawi's sacred Mount Mulanje added to UNESCO World Heritage List

“The concept of biosphere reserves is that biodiversity conservation is a pillar of socioeconomic development” and can contribute to the economy, said António Abreu, head of the programme, adding that conflict and misunderstanding can result if local communities are left out of decision-making and planning.

The new reserves, in 21 countries, were announced Saturday in Hangzhou, China, where the program adopted a 10-year strategic action plan that includes studying the effects of climate change, Abreu said.

The new reserves include a 52,000-square-mile (135,000-square-kilometre) area in the Indonesian archipelago, Raja Ampat, home to over 75 percent of earth’s coral species as well as rainforests and rare endangered sea turtles. The economy depends on fishing, aquaculture, small-scale agriculture and tourism, UNESCO said.

Antelopes huddle in the bush after being released in the Quicama National Park September 16, 2000, about 75 kilometres (47 miles) south of Angola's capital of Luanda. © Armando Franca, AP

On Iceland's west coast, the Snæfellsnes Biosphere Reserve's landscape includes volcanic peaks, lava fields, wetlands, grasslands and the Snæfellsjökull glacier. The 1,460-square-kilometre (564 square-mile) reserve is an important sanctuary for seabirds, seals and over 70 percent of Iceland's plant life – including 330 species of wildflowers and ferns. Its population of more than 4,000 people relies on fishing, sheep farming and tourism.

And in Angola, the new Quiçama Biosphere Reserve, along 206 kilometres (128 miles) of Atlantic coast is a “sanctuary for biodiversity” within its savannahs, forests, flood plains, estuaries and islands, according to UNESCO. It's home to elephants, manatees, sea turtles and more than 200 bird species. Residents' livelihoods include livestock herding, farming, fishing, honey production.

Residents are important partners in protecting biodiversity within the reserves, and even have helped identify new species, said Abreu, the program's leader. Meanwhile, scientists also are helping to restore ecosystems to benefit the local economy, he said.

Read moreThe Bright Side: Earth's ozone layer is healing thanks to international action, UN says

For example, in the Philippines, the coral reefs around Pangatalan Island were severely damaged because local fishermen used dynamite to find depleted fish populations. Scientists helped design a structure to help coral reefs regrow and taught fishermen to raise fish through aquaculture so the reefs could recover.

“They have food and they have also fish to sell in the markets,” said Abreu.

In the African nation of Sao Tome and Príncipe, a biosphere reserve on Príncipe Island led to restoration of mangroves, which help buffer against storm surges and provide important habitat, Abreu said.

Ecotourism also has become an important industry, with biosphere trails and guided bird-watching tours. A new species of owl was identified there in recent years.

A manta ray swims in the water near Raja Ampat islands, Indonesia, October 18, 2011. © AP, Herman Harsoyo

This year, a biosphere reserve was added for the island of Sao Tome, making the country the first entirely within a reserve.

At least 60 percent of the UNESCO biosphere reserves have been affected by extreme weather tied to climate change, which is caused primarily by the burning of fossil fuels such as coal and gas, including extreme heat and drought and sea-level rise, Abreu said.

The agency is using satellite imagery and computer modelling to monitor changes in coastal zones and other areas, and is digitising its historical databases, Abreu said. The information will be used to help determine how best to preserve and manage the reserves.

Read moreThe Bright Side: Hong Kong scientist fights to save endangered cockatoos

Some biosphere reserves also are under pressure from environmental degradation.

In Nigeria, for example, habitat for a dwindling population of critically endangered African forest elephants is under threat as cocoa farmers expand into Omo Forest Reserve, a protected rainforest and one of Africa’s oldest and largest UNESCO Biosphere Reserves. The forest is also important to help combat climate change.

The Trump administration in July announced that the US would withdraw from UNESCO as of December 2026, just as it did during his first administration, saying US involvement is not in the national interest. The US has 47 biosphere reserves, most in federal protected areas.

(FRANCE 24 with AP)

These reserves balance conservation with local socioeconomic development, involving communities and scientific research. The story highlights broad environmental impact, international cooperation, and concrete actions benefiting ecosystems and people worldwide.
articles.personality_title: UNESCO adds 26 new biosphere reserves to protect nature and support communities
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – UNESCO, the United Nations cultural agency, has been designating biosphere reserves since 1971. These special areas protect important ecosystems while including local people who live and work there. The goal is to balance nature conservation with human activities.

**What happened** – On August 8, 2025, UNESCO announced 26 new biosphere reserves across 21 countries. These include Lake Bourget in the French Alps, a rich area with over 6,100 species, and the marshes between France’s Loire and Vilaine rivers. Other new reserves are in Indonesia’s Raja Ampat islands, Iceland’s Snæfellsnes coast, and Angola’s Quiçama region. Each place is home to unique plants, animals, and local communities.

**Impact** – These new reserves protect some of the world’s most fragile ecosystems, like coral reefs, forests, and wetlands. They also show how people and nature can thrive together. For example, in the Philippines, scientists helped fishermen grow fish in safer ways, allowing coral reefs to recover. In Sao Tome and Príncipe, mangrove restoration helps protect against storms. The reserves support economies through fishing, farming, and ecotourism, while encouraging cooperation between scientists, governments, and residents.

**What's next step** – UNESCO will use satellite images and computer models to monitor these reserves and study how climate change affects them. The organization also adopted a 10-year plan to improve protection and research. Local communities will continue to play a key role in managing these areas and discovering new species.

**One-sentence takeaway** – UNESCO’s designation of 26 new biosphere reserves shows how protecting nature and involving local people can work together to support both the environment and communities worldwide.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'UNESCO désigne 26 nouvelles réserves de biosphère pour protéger la nature et soutenir les communautés
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L'UNESCO, l'agence culturelle des Nations Unies, désigne des réserves de biosphère depuis 1971. Ces zones spéciales protègent des écosystèmes importants tout en incluant les populations locales qui y vivent et travaillent. L'objectif est d'équilibrer la conservation de la nature avec les activités humaines.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 8 août 2025, l'UNESCO a annoncé 26 nouvelles réserves de biosphère dans 21 pays. Parmi elles, le lac du Bourget dans les Alpes françaises, riche de plus de 6 100 espèces, et les marais entre les rivières Loire et Vilaine. D'autres nouvelles réserves se trouvent dans l'archipel Raja Ampat en Indonésie, la côte de Snæfellsnes en Islande et la région de Quiçama en Angola. Chaque lieu abrite des plantes, des animaux et des communautés uniques.

**Impact** – Ces nouvelles réserves protègent certains des écosystèmes les plus fragiles du monde, comme les récifs coralliens, les forêts et les zones humides. Elles montrent aussi comment les humains et la nature peuvent prospérer ensemble. Par exemple, aux Philippines, des scientifiques ont aidé des pêcheurs à élever des poissons de manière plus sûre, permettant aux récifs coralliens de se régénérer. Les communautés locales continueront à jouer un rôle clé dans la gestion de ces zones et la découverte de nouvelles espèces.

**En une phrase** – La désignation par l'UNESCO de 26 nouvelles réserves de biosphère montre comment la protection de la nature et l'implication des populations locales peuvent s’allier pour soutenir à la fois l’environnement et les communautés dans le monde entier.
articles.personality_title_es: La UNESCO designa 26 nuevas reservas de biosfera para proteger la naturaleza y apoyar a las comunidades
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La UNESCO, la agencia cultural de las Naciones Unidas, ha designado reservas de biosfera desde 1971. Estas áreas especiales protegen ecosistemas importantes e incluyen a las personas que viven y trabajan allí. El objetivo es equilibrar la conservación de la naturaleza con las actividades humanas.

**Qué pasó** – El 8 de agosto de 2025, la UNESCO anunció 26 nuevas reservas de biosfera en 21 países. Entre ellas está el lago Bourget en los Alpes franceses, un área con más de 6,100 especies, y los pantanos entre los ríos Loira y Vilaine. Otras nuevas reservas están en las islas Raja Ampat de Indonesia, la costa de Snæfellsnes en Islandia y la región de Quiçama en Angola. Cada lugar alberga plantas, animales y comunidades únicas.

**Impacto** – Estas nuevas reservas protegen algunos de los ecosistemas más frágiles del mundo, como arrecifes de coral, bosques y humedales. También muestran cómo las personas y la naturaleza pueden prosperar juntas. Por ejemplo, en Filipinas, científicos ayudaron a los pescadores a criar peces de manera segura, permitiendo que los arrecifes de coral se recuperaran. En Santo Tomé y Príncipe, la restauración de manglares ayuda a proteger contra tormentas. Las reservas apoyan economías locales a través de la pesca, la agricultura y el ecoturismo, fomentando la cooperación entre científicos, gobiernos y residentes.

**Próximo paso** – La UNESCO usará imágenes satelitales y modelos por computadora para monitorear estas reservas y estudiar cómo el cambio climático las afecta. La organización adoptó un plan estratégico de 10 años para mejorar la protección y la investigación. Las comunidades locales seguirán siendo clave para gestionar estas áreas y descubrir nuevas especies.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La designación de 26 nuevas reservas de biosfera por parte de la UNESCO demuestra cómo proteger la naturaleza junto con la participación de las comunidades locales puede beneficiar tanto al medio ambiente como a las personas en todo el mundo.

articles.title: China pledges to cut emissions by 2035: what does that mean for the climate?
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 26 September 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03166-6The country’s plan to reduce greenhouse gases will largely determine the world’s emissions trajectory, researchers say.
articles.content:
Credit: AFP via Getty

China has revealed its goal for slashing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, providing a glimpse into how global emissions might change over the next decade. In a video address to the United Nations Climate Summit on 24 September, Chinese president Xi Jinping announced that China will reduce greenhouse-gas emissions by 7% to 10% from peak levels by 2035.

The pace at which China cuts emissions will have profound global impact. The country has accounted for 90% of the growth in the world’s CO ₂ emissions since 2015 and it is now the largest GHG emitter in the world, responsible for around one-third of the global total, according to the Asia Society Policy Institute, a think tank based in New York City. Analysts have warned that China’s action could make or break the 2015 Paris agreement.

In 2020, Xi pledged that China’s CO ₂ emissions would peak before 2030 and that the country would achieve carbon neutrality before 2060. Some researchers say China’s CO ₂ emissions will probably peak soon if they haven’t already.

The latest targets are part of China’s new Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC), a climate-action plan that all countries subject to the Paris agreement must submit to the UN every five years. China also set clean-energy targets for 2035.

The importance of China’s latest NDC is that its targets cover the years until 2035, past the country’s proposed peak, says Yao Zhe, a Beijing-based researcher of China’s climate policy at Greenpeace East Asia. “This is the first time China has officially outlined its post-peaking plan,” Yao says.

Once China’s emissions drop, global emissions will likely start to drop, says Belinda Schäpe, a China analyst at the Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air (CREA), a Helsinki-based think tank. “That's why these targets are so important for the global community, because they can help them understand” how the world’s emissions trajectory could look, she says.

This is also the first time that China has announced a target that covers not only carbon dioxide (CO ₂ ) but all GHGs including methane and nitrous oxide, says Zhang Da, who researches energy economics and climate change at Tsinghua University in Beijing.

Ambitious or not?

Some researchers think that China’s emissions-reduction target falls short of what the world needs to achieve the Paris agreement’s aim, of limiting global warming to well below 2 °C above pre-industrial levels, and striving to stay below 1.5 °C.

“Anything less than 20% is definitely not aligned with 2 degrees. Similarly, anything less than 30% is definitely not aligned with 1.5 degrees,” says Lauri Myllyvirta, an analyst who has tracked China’s emissions trends for more than a decade and is CREA’s co-founder. Myllyvirta cites his analysis of a set of future climate scenarios used by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change to help the world adhere to the Paris Agreement.

The way China has defined its emissions cuts — as 7–10% of an undefined amount, rather than specifying a year as the basis for calculation – leaves the door open for short-term emissions increases, Myllyvirta says.

The different pathways for China to achieve carbon neutrality between 2030 and 2060 could result in different amounts of cumulative emissions, says Myllyvirta. “What matters for the climate is the total amount of GHGs emitted into the atmosphere over time,” he says, adding that this is why cutting emissions fast early on is important.

But others, such as Da, regard China’s target an important step. “Reducing non-CO ₂ emissions is typically more challenging than mitigating CO ₂ ,” says Da. “A 7–10% reduction in net GHG emissions from peak levels usually implies a higher level of CO ₂ reduction.”
articles.reasoning: China's official pledge to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 7-10% from peak levels by 2035 represents a significant and concrete climate action with broad global impact, given China's large share of global emissions. The announcement includes a comprehensive target covering all greenhouse gases and extends beyond previous commitments, providing clarity on China's post-peak emissions strategy. While some experts consider the target insufficient to meet the Paris Agreement goals, the plan is a meaningful step towards global emissions reduction and climate stabilization.

Other countries will watch closely to see how China meets its goals, and the global community will use this information to adjust climate efforts worldwide.

articles.personality_title_fr: La Chine s'engage à réduire ses émissions de gaz à effet de serre de 7 à 10 % d'ici 2035
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Chine est le plus grand émetteur mondial de gaz à effet de serre, responsable d'environ un tiers des émissions mondiales. Depuis 2015, la Chine a contribué à 90 % de l'augmentation des émissions mondiales de dioxyde de carbone. Le pays avait déjà promis un pic d'émissions avant 2030 et la neutralité carbone d'ici 2060.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 24 septembre 2025, le président chinois Xi Jinping a annoncé lors du Sommet des Nations Unies sur le climat que la Chine réduira ses émissions de gaz à effet de serre de 7 à 10 % par rapport à leur niveau maximal d'ici 2035. Ce plan fait partie de la nouvelle Contribution Déterminée au niveau National (CDN) de la Chine, un engagement quinquennal dans le cadre de l'Accord de Paris. Pour la première fois, la cible couvre tous les gaz à effet de serre, pas seulement le dioxyde de carbone.

**Impact** – L'engagement de la Chine est important car ses émissions influencent fortement la trajectoire mondiale. Si la Chine réduit ses émissions, celles du monde entier devraient aussi diminuer. Ce plan donne aussi des informations claires sur la stratégie chinoise après le pic d'émissions, aidant les autres pays à mieux comprendre les efforts climatiques mondiaux. Certains experts jugent que l'objectif est peut-être insuffisant pour atteindre les buts de l'Accord de Paris, mais c'est un progrès significatif.

**Prochaine étape** – La Chine va travailler à mettre en œuvre ce plan en développant les énergies propres et en réduisant les gaz nocifs comme le méthane et le protoxyde d'azote. Les autres pays suivront de près pour voir comment la Chine atteindra ses objectifs, et la communauté mondiale ajustera ses propres actions climatiques en conséquence.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La nouvelle cible chinoise de réduction des gaz à effet de serre de 7 à 10 % d'ici 2035 montre clairement sa stratégie après le pic d’émissions et influence l’avenir des émissions mondiales.
articles.personality_title_es: China se compromete a reducir sus emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero entre un 7 y un 10 % para 2035
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – China es el mayor emisor de gases de efecto invernadero del mundo, responsable de aproximadamente un tercio de las emisiones globales. Desde 2015, China ha contribuido al 90 % del aumento de las emisiones mundiales de dióxido de carbono. El país ya había prometido alcanzar el pico de emisiones antes de 2030 y lograr la neutralidad de carbono para 2060.

**Qué pasó** – El 24 de septiembre de 2025, el presidente chino Xi Jinping anunció en la Cumbre Climática de las Naciones Unidas que China reducirá sus emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero entre un 7 y un 10 % desde los niveles máximos para 2035. Este plan forma parte de la nueva Contribución Determinada a Nivel Nacional (NDC) de China, que presenta objetivos climáticos cada cinco años bajo el Acuerdo de París. Por primera vez, la meta cubre todos los gases de efecto invernadero, no solo el dióxido de carbono.

**Impacto** – El compromiso de China es importante porque sus emisiones tienen un gran peso en la trayectoria global. Si China reduce sus emisiones, es probable que las emisiones mundiales también disminuyan. El plan también ofrece información clara sobre la estrategia de China después de alcanzar su pico de emisiones, ayudando a otros países a entender cómo podrían avanzar los esfuerzos climáticos globales. Aunque algunos expertos consideran que la meta no es suficiente para cumplir los objetivos del Acuerdo de París, sigue siendo un paso significativo.

**Próximo paso** – China trabajará para implementar este plan aumentando la energía limpia y reduciendo gases dañinos como el metano y el óxido nitroso. Otros países observarán de cerca cómo China cumple sus objetivos, y la comunidad internacional usará esta información para ajustar sus esfuerzos climáticos.

**Resumen en una frase** – La nueva meta de China de reducir sus emisiones de gases de efecto invernadero entre un 7 y un 10 % para 2035 establece un camino claro para sus acciones tras el pico y afecta el futuro de las emisiones globales.
